attributes.title: Stock Take
attributes.description:
•    Physical stock counted compared to SAP warehouse balances indicated variances as follows; Bread had +43.75 loaves, White ingredients 18kg had -4bags, White ingredients 9kg had +8bags, while Polybags had +535 pieces. The rest of the stock items had zero or minimal variances.

The table below illustrates the findings.
attributes.recommendation: •    Stock controls in place should be maintained to safeguard all stock items
attributes.effect: •    Minimal stock variations is indication of adequate controls in place.

value: •    We shall ensure we maintain to avoid losses associated with stock variances
•    The controls in the branch are good and we shall continue to enhance.

•    In prior audit, The following were the stock findings;
•    Bread  -53.75loaves
•    Cumulative variance in polybags was +252 pieces
•    All other materials had negligible variances.

•    Stock take was conducted on 12th April 2025 to establish whether the physical stocks were matching with the stock book balance generated from SAP system and whether internal controls on stocks were effective.
Stock items are well controlled and this should be maintained.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure stock items are properly controlled.

attributes.title: Bread Weight
attributes.description: •    From the samples picked, bread underweight were noted across all varieties with prevalent cases in 600g white bread and 200g mini loaf as illustrated below.
attributes.recommendation: •    Underweight cases should be discouraged. The production team should ensure that the prescribed production parameters are adhered to at all stages.
attributes.effect:
•    Presence of underweight bread is an indication that the company is exposed to the risk of penalties if caught by weight and measure officials.
•    Supplying underweight bread can also lead customer dissatisfaction.

value:
•    We do random checks on bread production process to ensure we produce bread within the recommended weight standards. 
•    Overcooling also contributes to underweight products
•    The branch team shall be tasked to ensure finished products are within the weight standards.

•    In prior audit, on 06.03.2025 underweight bread was as follows; 200g OT - 22.67%, 400g CT – 8%,
600g CT – 18.67%, 800g CT – 6.67% and 1.5kg CT – 17.33%.

•    Bread weight check was done from a sample selected from packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market. The aim was to establish whether the bread dispatched to the market meets the required weight standards.
•    Presence of underweight bread is an indication that the company is exposed to the risk of penalties if caught by weight and measure officials, this this should be worked to caution the company.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure that bread produced and dispatched to the market meets the minimum weight standards

attributes.title: Damages Analysis
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that production damages were averaging at 0.36% of the total production and market damages stood at 0.33% of the total sales. 
•    Physical damages weighed compared to Manager’s records over the same period had a variance of -29.90kg equivalent to 74.75 loaves worth Kes. 3,961.75 (using mini shop price).
Production damages analysis;
attributes.recommendation: •    The management should ensure there is adherence with production procedures to control damages related to production.
attributes.effect: •    Production damages recorded for the period exceeded the set threshold exposing the company to a revenue loss of Kes 101,442

value: •    We have tried to control the damages but still not at the recommended level. We shall to follow the laid out production procedures.
•    Though this improved from the previous audit, more effort shall be employed to bring production damages to the desired level.

•    In the previous audit 0n 06.03.2025, Production damages were at 0.41% while market damages were at 0.47%.
•    Bread damages verification revealed a Negative variance of 29.90kg equivalent to 74.75 loaves

•    Analysis of production and market damages was done for a period of 33 days from 10th Mar 2025 to 11th April 2025 to determine whether production and market damages were within the desired percentages of 0.20% of the total production and 0.50% of the total sales respectively.
Market damages were well controlled during the period under review whereas Production damages exceeded the set threshold exposing the company revenue losses.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure the bread produced is of good quality and that in case of any damages, they remain within the set thresholds.

attributes.title: Mixing Charts Analysis
attributes.description:
•    Below is a summary of SAP production data compared to physical mixing data below;

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

•    It was noted that, Average production was 189.64 bags per day, which is 84% of the daily target of 225 bags. Yield achieved during the period was 191.19.

•    The table below shows summarized findings of the mixing chart production analysis.
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch should capitalize on available production capacity of 225bags.
•    Sales team should explore new markets given that the production capacity is high.
attributes.effect: •    The branch's production capacity utilization was at 84% of the full available capacity, leaving an idle capacity of 16%. This indicates that the branch did not fully capitalize on economies of scale.

value: •    Production is planned as per orders otherwise we are capable of doing 225 bags.
•    We plan production as per route orders.

•    In the previous audit, there was no significant variance between system and the actual material consumption.
•    Correct posting was also noted over the audited period.

•    An analysis of mixing chart summaries was done for a period of 33 days from 10th Mar 2025 to 11th April 2025, to confirm production data accuracy from mixing charts to cash flow and SAP, raw materials usage as per the set BOM, production yield and if the set production standards were achieved.
There is still room for increased production in case there is need to.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure data accuracy from mixing charts to cash flow and SAP, raw materials usage as per the set BOM, production yield and if the set production standards were achieved.

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
•    Cash counted compared to cash flow balance had a Nil variance 
•    There were five pending IOU’s amounting to Kes. 60,002 as illustrated below.
attributes.recommendation: •    The branch cashier should maintain the cash controls in place
attributes.effect: •    Nil cash variance implies that adequate cash controls are in place.

value: •    This is well noted
•    Well noted, we shall maintain.
•    In the previous audit, Minimal variances were noted during spot-check.
•    Verification of cash held at the cash office on 13th April 2025, to confirm cash held by the cashier matches the expected cash and whether the set cash operation standards are adhered to.
The controls in the cash office are adequate.
Finance Department
To confirm cash held by the cashier matches the expected cash and whether the set cash operation standards are adhered to.

attributes.title: Mini shop spot check
attributes.description: •    Mini shop bread balance and sales proceed were properly accounted as illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation: •    The controls in place at the mini shop were found to be adequate and are operating effectively. It is recommended that these controls be maintained to ensure continued compliance and operational efficiency.
attributes.effect: •    The operations were carried out in accordance with established standards, as evidenced by the minimal variance observed.

value: •    This is well noted. We shall maintain the controls.
•    This shall maintained.
•    A spot check was conducted in the mini shop on 12th April 2025 to assess whether the operation were being carried out in accordance with the established standards.
The shop is well run and in accordance with the laid down procedures.
Sales Department
To assess whether the operation were being carried out in accordance with the established standards.

attributes.title: Debtors analysis
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that, the total outstanding debtors amounted to Kes 505, 048. It was further noted that most of outstanding cases were involving turn boys who have since left employment. 

Route Balances
attributes.recommendation:
•    Sales crew and the sales representative to ensure that bread supplied is paid for on delivery for customers without credit arrangement.
•    The management should reassess the hiring practices and strengthen background checks for potential turn boys.
attributes.effect: •    Outstanding route balances for customers without a credit arrangement may result in bad debts, leading to potential financial losses.

value: •    Sales Rep and the TSM are following cases involving Turn boys
•    Cases involving Turn boys are still undergoing.
•    In the previous audit, outstanding debts for customers was Kshs. 310,946.25.
•    An analysis of the route balances was done as at 12th April 2025 to ascertain the status thereof.
There is need to reassess the recruitment process of turnboys going forward.
Sales Department
To assess the extent of exposure to the company through outstanding debts.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that the production efficiency was 4.55 bags per production worker. 

A summary of production analysis is shown below;
attributes.recommendation: •    The controls on production workers should be maintained.
attributes.effect: •    The production efficiency achieved was 4.55, which is above the KPI, implying that production labour was well controlled.

value: •    We shall ensure we continue to manage our workers efficiently.
•    This is well noted, we shall maintain.
•    In the prior audit, Analysis was done from 01/02/2025 - 28/02/2025 production efficiency was at 4.58 bags per production worker

•    Production efficiency was calculated for period of 33 days from 10th Mar 2025 to 11th Mar 2025. The aim was to determine if the production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker.
The production labour  employed is well managed hence the efficiency.
Operations/Production Department
To ascertain whether production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker.

attributes.title: Packing efficiency
attributes.description:
•    Analysis revealed that the average slicing efficiency for the period was 92.30 crates per slicer. 

The table below illustrates the findings;-
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should ensure packers hired are well controlled to eliminate the inefficiency.
attributes.effect: •    The packing efficiency achieved was 92.30. The resulting inefficiency led to increase in production labour cost by Kes. 38,304.

value: •    We are closely monitoring our packers to ensure the inefficiency is eliminated
•    The branch Manager and supervisors to ensure packers are efficiently supervised.
•    In the prior audit, Analysis which was done from 01/02/2025 - 28/02/2025 and packing efficiency was at 90.89 crates per slicer.
•    Slicing efficiency was calculated over a 33-day period, from 10th March 2025, to 11th April 2025, to determine whether the KPI of 97 crates per slicer was being met.
Packing workers hired are not optimally managed.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure there is efficient management of packing workers hired.

attributes.title: Motor Vehicle Fuel Consumption
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that KCF 206S Siaya Route, KDL 257U – Bondo were overconsuming while KBQ 211J – Alego, KCM 881A – Kisumu supermarkets, KDL 253U – Lolwe and KCH 932N - Pacho were saving fuel as per the set rate standards.
•    Mileage analysis illustration table is annexed below.
attributes.recommendation: •    Further investigation into vehicle consumption should be conducted, and standard rates should be adjusted to align with current actual consumption levels.
attributes.effect: •    Variations in fuel consumption from the standard rates affect cost budgeting and planning.

value: •    Our records shows some of our sales vans had variances in consumption during the month of March, we are closely during this month of April.
•    Manager to ensure that vehicles consumption are within standards and where variance are noted we shall do investigation.
•    In the prior audit, Fuel consumption analysis showed that all sales vans fuel consumption was within the expected range.
•    Motor vehicle fuel consumption analysis was done for the period 1st March 2025 to 31st March 2025. To evaluate compliance with set fuel standard for each vehicle.
There were variances on fuel consumptions on various routes. further investigations is recommended to establish the correct consumption rate and alignment done.
Transport/Fleet Department
To evaluate fuel consumption as per established the standard rates.
